concepts.description: Pupils check and correct spelling and punctuation mistakes by re-reading their writing, monitoring meaning as they write
concepts.teaching_guidance: Consolidate proof-reading skills, teaching children to check systematically for spelling, punctuation and grammatical accuracy. Teach multi-pass proof-reading: read once for spelling (touching each word), once for punctuation (checking sentence boundaries), and once for grammar (reading aloud for sense). Provide year-group-specific proof-reading checklists that include Year 4 expectations: apostrophes for possession, commas after fronted adverbials, speech punctuation, consistent tense, and accurate spelling of statutory word list words.
concepts.key_vocabulary: proof-read, check, correct, spelling, punctuation, grammar, error, accuracy, systematic, checklist
concepts.common_misconceptions: Children may skim-read when proof-reading, reading what they intended rather than what they wrote. They may check for one type of error but miss others. Some children introduce new errors when correcting existing ones because they do not reread the corrected sentence. Others may declare their work 'perfect' without actually checking it carefully.

concepts.description: Pupils present their writing orally to a group or whole class with appropriate intonation, controlling tone and volume so that meaning is clear
concepts.teaching_guidance: Provide regular opportunities for children to read their own writing aloud, treating it as a performance that communicates their work to an audience. In Year 4, increase expectations for expression: children should vary pace, volume and tone to reflect the mood and meaning of their writing. Use peer response: listeners identify specific effective moments and ask questions. Connect reading aloud to the editing process — children often notice weaknesses in their writing when they hear it spoken. Encourage children to read aloud different types of writing: stories, poems, information texts and persuasive writing.
concepts.key_vocabulary: read aloud, perform, expression, intonation, pace, volume, audience, communicate, share, respond
concepts.common_misconceptions: Children may rush through reading their own work because they are self-conscious. They may read aloud without expression because they are concentrating on decoding their own handwriting. Some children ad-lib improvements as they read rather than reading what is actually written, which defeats the purpose of using reading aloud as an editing tool.

concepts.description: Pupils extend the range of sentences with more than one clause by using a wider range of conjunctions, including when, if, because, although, creating subordinate clauses for varied effect
concepts.teaching_guidance: Consolidate and extend multi-clause sentence writing. In Year 4, children should use a wider range of subordinating conjunctions (although, while, until, since, unless, wherever) alongside co-ordinating conjunctions (and, but, or, so, yet). Teach children to vary sentence length and structure deliberately: short sentences for impact, longer multi-clause sentences for explanation and description. Model parsing complex sentences to identify clauses. Use sentence-combining and sentence-expanding activities to develop flexibility.
concepts.key_vocabulary: clause, multi-clause, conjunction, although, while, until, since, subordinate, co-ordinate, vary, sentence
concepts.common_misconceptions: Children may write multi-clause sentences that are grammatically tangled, losing track of the main clause among multiple subordinate clauses. They may use 'when' and 'because' as their default subordinating conjunctions without varying their repertoire. Some children write either all simple sentences or all complex sentences, lacking the ability to vary for effect.

concepts.description: Pupils understand and use the present perfect form of verbs (have/has + past participle) in contrast to the simple past tense, understanding the difference in meaning and when each is appropriate
concepts.teaching_guidance: Consolidate the present perfect tense by providing regular practice in Year 4 writing. Teach children to choose between the simple past and present perfect with awareness of the difference in meaning: 'I ate lunch' (completed) vs 'I have eaten lunch' (relevant to now). Practise with irregular past participles that cause common errors: gone (not went), done (not did), seen (not saw), written (not wrote), taken (not took). Use dictation and editing activities to reinforce correct usage.
concepts.key_vocabulary: present perfect, has, have, past participle, tense, simple past, irregular, gone, done, seen, written
concepts.common_misconceptions: Children commonly use the simple past form instead of the past participle with 'has/have' (e.g., 'I have went' instead of 'I have gone', 'She has wrote' instead of 'She has written'). They may not understand when to use the present perfect versus the simple past. Some children avoid the present perfect entirely because they find it confusing.

concepts.description: Pupils choose nouns or pronouns appropriately for clarity and cohesion within and across sentences, avoiding repetition while ensuring pronoun references are clear
concepts.teaching_guidance: Develop pronoun use for cohesion in Year 4, focusing on clear and unambiguous pronoun reference. Teach children to check that every pronoun has a clear antecedent — the reader should always know who or what the pronoun refers to. Use editing activities where children identify unclear pronoun reference and revise for clarity. Teach possessive pronouns (his, her, its, their, our, your, my) and demonstrative pronouns (this, that, these, those) alongside personal pronouns. Model choosing between nouns and pronouns for variety and clarity during shared writing.
concepts.key_vocabulary: pronoun, cohesion, reference, antecedent, clear, ambiguous, he, she, they, it, his, her, their
concepts.common_misconceptions: Children frequently use pronouns ambiguously, particularly in narratives with characters of the same gender (e.g., 'Tom told Harry that he was late' — who was late?). They may overuse pronouns, creating passages where the referent is unclear. Conversely, some children avoid pronouns and repeat nouns excessively, producing stilted writing.

concepts.concept_name: Conjunctions, adverbs and prepositions for time and cause
concepts.description: Pupils use conjunctions (when, before, after, while, so, because), adverbs (then, next, soon, therefore) and prepositions (before, after, during, in, because of) to express time, place and cause in writing
concepts.teaching_guidance: Extend children's use of conjunctions, adverbs and prepositions to express time, cause and purpose. Year 4 additions include: purpose conjunctions (so that, in order to), concessive conjunctions (although, even though), and a wider range of adverbials (meanwhile, consequently, as a result, in contrast). Teach children to use these connectives to build logical relationships between ideas in both narrative and non-fiction writing. Display a connectives menu organised by function (time, cause, contrast, addition, purpose) for reference during writing.
concepts.key_vocabulary: conjunction, adverb, preposition, time, cause, purpose, although, meanwhile, consequently, so that
concepts.common_misconceptions: Children may overuse one connective function (usually time: 'then... then... then...') without using causal, contrastive or purposive connectives. They may use connectives incorrectly, placing 'however' where 'because' is needed. Some children sprinkle connectives into their writing without understanding the logical relationship they signal.

concepts.description: Pupils understand and use fronted adverbials placed at the start of sentences for effect (e.g. Later that day, I heard the bad news.) and use commas after them
concepts.teaching_guidance: Consolidate the use of fronted adverbials in Year 4, extending the range of adverbial types. Teach time adverbials (Later that evening, After several attempts), place adverbials (Beyond the hedge, At the top of the hill), manner adverbials (Cautiously, With great care), and frequency adverbials (Often, Every morning). Ensure children always use a comma after a fronted adverbial. Model using fronted adverbials to improve the opening of sentences and to create variety in sentence structure. Avoid overuse — not every sentence should begin with a fronted adverbial.
concepts.key_vocabulary: fronted adverbial, comma, time, place, manner, sentence opener, variety, adverbial phrase, position
concepts.common_misconceptions: Children commonly forget the comma after a fronted adverbial. They may overuse fronted adverbials, starting every sentence with one, creating a repetitive pattern. Some children confuse fronted adverbials with conjunctions and produce sentence fragments. Others use only single-word adverbials rather than adverbial phrases.

concepts.description: Pupils use and punctuate direct speech fully, using inverted commas and other punctuation to indicate direct speech, including a comma after the reporting clause and end punctuation within inverted commas (e.g. The conductor shouted, "Sit down!")
concepts.teaching_guidance: Consolidate direct speech punctuation by practising more complex dialogue structures. Teach: speech before the reporting clause ('Hello,' said Tom.), speech after the reporting clause (Tom said, 'Hello.'), speech interrupted by the reporting clause ('Hello,' said Tom, 'how are you?'), and new speaker on a new line. Practise varying reporting verbs beyond 'said': whispered, exclaimed, asked, replied, muttered, announced. Use drama to generate natural-sounding dialogue that children then punctuate correctly in writing.
concepts.key_vocabulary: speech marks, inverted commas, dialogue, reporting clause, said, asked, replied, new line, comma, punctuation
concepts.common_misconceptions: Children frequently misplace speech marks, particularly forgetting to close them or placing them around the reporting clause as well as the speech. They may not place the comma before the closing speech mark. The interrupted speech pattern ('Hello,' said Tom, 'how are you?') is particularly challenging. Some children put speech marks around reported speech.

concepts.description: Pupils expand noun phrases by adding modifying adjectives, nouns and preposition phrases (e.g. the teacher expanded to: the strict maths teacher with curly hair) to build more precise and varied descriptions
concepts.teaching_guidance: Develop the use of expanded noun phrases with modifiers before and after the noun. In Year 4, extend beyond adjective + noun to include prepositional phrases after the noun: 'the old man with a walking stick', 'the abandoned house on the hill', 'a small kitten with bright green eyes'. Teach children to use expanded noun phrases for precise, vivid description rather than vague generality. Model choosing noun phrases that create specific images in the reader's mind. Connect to reading — identify and discuss effective noun phrases in class texts.
concepts.key_vocabulary: noun phrase, expanded, modifier, adjective, prepositional phrase, describe, detail, precise, vivid, image
concepts.common_misconceptions: Children may add modifiers that are redundant or contradictory ('a big enormous giant'). They may not realise that noun phrases can include information after the noun as well as before it. Some children produce noun phrases that are overloaded with modifiers, making sentences unwieldy and difficult to read.

concepts.description: Pupils understand and apply the grammatical difference between the plural -s (indicating more than one) and the possessive -s (indicating ownership), including with irregular plurals
concepts.teaching_guidance: Teach the distinction between plural -s and possessive -s (and possessive s') explicitly in Year 4, as this is a persistent source of error. Use the test: if you can replace '-s' with 'belongs to', it is possessive and needs an apostrophe; if it simply means 'more than one', it is plural and does not. Provide sorting and editing activities: children categorise words ending in -s as plural or possessive and add apostrophes where needed. Practise in sentence contexts to build automaticity.
concepts.key_vocabulary: plural, possessive, apostrophe, -s, 's, belongs to, more than one, singular, grammar, distinguish
concepts.common_misconceptions: This is one of the most common errors in children's writing across all year groups. Children may add apostrophes to all words ending in -s ('the apple's are red') or omit them from all possessives ('the girls coat'). They may know the rule but fail to apply it consistently in independent writing because it requires pausing to consider whether each -s is plural or possessive.

concepts.description: Pupils use Standard English forms for verb inflections instead of local spoken forms (e.g. we were instead of we was, or I did instead of I done), understanding the difference between Standard and non-Standard English
concepts.teaching_guidance: Teach Standard English verb inflections that differ from non-standard dialect forms. Focus on the key distinctions: 'we were' (not 'we was'), 'I did' (not 'I done'), 'she saw' (not 'she seen'), 'they went' (not 'they gone'), 'he ran' (not 'he run'), 'we have' (not 'we has'). Use editing activities where children identify and correct non-standard verb forms in written text. Approach sensitively: Standard English is expected in writing and formal speech, but dialect is a valid and valued form of communication in other contexts.
concepts.key_vocabulary: Standard English, verb, inflection, we were, I did, she saw, they went, correct, formal, written
concepts.common_misconceptions: Children who speak a non-standard dialect may not hear a difference between 'I done it' and 'I did it', making it difficult to correct in writing. They may apply corrections inconsistently. Some children feel that correcting their verb forms is criticising their home language. Others may overcorrect, producing hypercorrect forms ('I were going').

concepts.concept_name: Paragraphs to organise ideas around a theme
concepts.description: Pupils use paragraphs to organise ideas around a theme in their writing, with appropriate choice of pronoun or noun within and across sentences to aid cohesion and avoid repetition
concepts.teaching_guidance: Develop paragraphing skills by teaching children to organise paragraphs around a clear theme or idea, with explicit topic sentences. In narrative, teach children to use paragraphs to control pace: short paragraphs for fast-paced action or tension, longer paragraphs for description and reflection. In non-fiction, teach that each paragraph should have a clear main idea supported by details, examples or evidence. Model linking paragraphs with cohesive devices that show the relationship between ideas.
concepts.key_vocabulary: paragraph, theme, topic sentence, organise, main idea, detail, evidence, link, cohesion, pace, structure
concepts.common_misconceptions: Children may write paragraphs without topic sentences, making it difficult for the reader to identify the main idea. They may not use linking devices between paragraphs, creating disjointed text. Some children understand paragraphing in one text type (usually non-fiction) but not in another (usually narrative).

concepts.description: Pupils learn and use Year 4 grammatical terminology accurately when discussing writing and reading: determiner, pronoun, possessive pronoun, adverbial (building on cumulative terminology from previous years)
concepts.teaching_guidance: Teach the Year 4 grammatical terminology from Appendix 2: determiner, pronoun, possessive pronoun, adverbial. Ensure children can both define these terms and identify examples in context. Teach 'determiner' as the broader category that includes articles (a, an, the), demonstratives (this, that, these, those), possessives (my, your, his, her, its, our, their) and quantifiers (some, many, every). Teach 'adverbial' as a word, phrase or clause that functions as an adverb, telling when, where, how or why.
concepts.key_vocabulary: determiner, pronoun, possessive pronoun, adverbial, article, demonstrative, function, identify, terminology
concepts.common_misconceptions: Children may struggle to understand 'determiner' as a category because it includes many different word types. They may confuse possessive pronouns (mine, yours, his, hers) with possessive determiners (my, your, his, her). Some children know the terminology but cannot explain the function of these elements in a sentence.

concepts.description: Pupils demonstrate understanding of figurative language, distinguish shades of meaning among related words, and use age-appropriate academic vocabulary to express and discuss ideas with precision
concepts.teaching_guidance: Introduce figurative language through reading: identify and discuss similes, metaphors, personification and onomatopoeia in class texts. Teach children to use figurative language purposefully in their own writing — to create vivid images, to compare unfamiliar things to familiar ones, and to engage the reader emotionally. Develop academic vocabulary through cross-curricular learning, teaching subject-specific terminology in science, history, geography and RE. Encourage children to use precise, ambitious vocabulary rather than defaulting to simple, familiar words.
concepts.key_vocabulary: figurative language, simile, metaphor, personification, onomatopoeia, academic vocabulary, precise, vivid
concepts.common_misconceptions: Children may use similes and metaphors that are clichéd ('as fast as lightning', 'a blanket of snow') rather than creating original comparisons. They may use figurative language excessively, producing overwritten prose. Some children confuse simile and metaphor. Others may use ambitious vocabulary incorrectly because they have encountered it in reading but not fully understood its meaning.

concepts.description: Pupils increasingly justify their views about what they have read independently by end of Year 4, having developed from supported justification at the start of Year 3 to full independence
concepts.teaching_guidance: Teach children to justify their views about books with increasing independence and specificity. Encourage children to go beyond 'I liked it because it was exciting' to explain what specifically made it exciting: character development, plot twists, descriptive language, relatable themes. Use book review frameworks that prompt children to evaluate specific aspects: character, setting, plot, language, themes, and overall impact. Teach children to support their views with direct reference to or quotation from the text.
concepts.key_vocabulary: justify, opinion, evidence, review, recommend, character, plot, theme, language, effective, because, quote
concepts.common_misconceptions: Children may give vague evaluative statements ('It was good') without specific justification. They may evaluate books purely on plot (whether they liked what happened) without considering the quality of writing, characterisation or themes. Some children find it difficult to explain why they did not enjoy a book without simply saying 'it was boring'.

concepts.description: Pupils read silently with good understanding, applying all comprehension strategies independently, and developing stamina for sustained independent reading
concepts.teaching_guidance: Continue developing silent reading stamina and comprehension in Year 4. Extend sustained silent reading periods to 15-20 minutes. Teach children to set a reading purpose before starting: 'I'm going to find out about...', 'I want to know what happens to...' Monitor silent reading comprehension through brief partner discussions, reading journals or teacher conferences. Ensure children are reading texts at an appropriate level — challenging enough to develop skills but not so difficult that comprehension breaks down. Teach children to self-select books at the right level.
concepts.key_vocabulary: silent reading, independent, sustained, comprehension, focus, concentrate, appropriate level, purpose, engage
concepts.common_misconceptions: Children may appear to be reading silently but actually be disengaged, turning pages without processing meaning. Some children choose books that are too easy because they are familiar and comfortable, missing opportunities for growth. Others choose books that are too difficult because of peer pressure or the status associated with thick books, and comprehension suffers.

prerequisite_relationships.rationale: Year 3 active listening skills develop into Year 4 more sophisticated and consistent active listening and response across a wider variety of contexts
Year 3 questioning skills develop into Year 4 more probing questions that extend understanding beyond surface meaning
Year 3 vocabulary building strategies develop into Year 4 wider and more systematic use of multiple strategies including etymology and morphology
Year 3 articulating opinions develops into Year 4 increasingly independent justification of views about what they read, with greater confidence and reasoning
Year 3 structured spoken descriptions develop into Year 4 well-structured, purpose-adapted descriptions, explanations and narratives
Year 3 collaborative conversation skills develop into Year 4 more sustained and constructive collaborative discussion with greater initiative
Year 3 exploratory talk develops into Year 4 more sophisticated use of talk as a genuine thinking tool for speculating and hypothesising
Year 3 audible and fluent speech develops into Year 4 increasing command of Standard English, beginning to distinguish Standard from non-Standard forms
Year 3 participation in performances and presentations develops into Year 4 greater confidence across a wider variety of formal and informal spoken contexts
Year 3 audience engagement skills develop into Year 4 active monitoring of listener interest with more sophisticated adaptation of delivery
Year 3 evaluating viewpoints develops into Year 4 more considered evaluation and constructive building on others' contributions
Year 3 register and audience awareness develops into Year 4 more deliberate and effective selection of appropriate registers, including Standard English in formal contexts
Year 3 root word knowledge develops into Year 4 growing application of etymology and morphology to comprehend new vocabulary, with comprehension now primary
Year 3 prefix and suffix knowledge develops into Year 4 wider application to read and understand new words, supported by trying different pronunciations for longer words
Year 3 exception words provide the foundation for Year 4 reading further exception words from the Years 3-4 statutory list, noting unusual correspondences
Year 3 positive attitudes to reading through wide exposure develops into Year 4 more independent choice and appreciation of diverse texts
Year 3 reading for different purposes develops into Year 4 understanding how text structure serves purpose across a wider range of text types
Year 3 dictionary use for reading comprehension develops into Year 4 efficient dictionary use supported by secure knowledge of spelling and alphabetical order
Year 3 familiarity with fairy stories, myths and legends develops into Year 4 deeper knowledge of themes and retelling skills with greater independence
Year 3 recognition of themes and conventions develops into Year 4 identification across a wider range of books with greater analytical independence
Year 3 poetry and play performance develops into Year 4 more polished performance with deeper understanding of how expression supports meaning
Year 3 appreciation of effective language develops into Year 4 more sophisticated discussion of vocabulary and exploration of word meaning and origin
Year 3 recognition of poetic forms develops into Year 4 broader recognition and appreciation of different forms of poetry
Year 3 comprehension monitoring develops into Year 4 more fluent and automatic monitoring of understanding during independent reading
Year 3 questioning for comprehension develops into Year 4 more independent formulation of questions, with pupils able to develop and evaluate rules for effective discussion
Year 3 drawing inferences with evidence develops into Year 4 more sophisticated and independently justified inference about characters' inner states
Year 3 prediction from stated and implied detail develops into Year 4 more confident use of textual evidence for prediction
Year 3 identifying main ideas develops into Year 4 synthesising main ideas drawn from more than one paragraph and creating accurate summaries
Year 3 understanding of how language, structure and presentation contribute to meaning develops into Year 4 more analytical identification of how authors deliberately use these features
Year 3 retrieving information from non-fiction develops into Year 4 more efficient retrieval and recording with clearer task awareness before beginning
Year 3 discussion about books develops into Year 4 fuller participation with expectation that all pupils contribute and with independently agreed rules for discussion
Year 3 prefix and suffix spelling rules develop into Year 4 consolidation and extension of those rules across further prefixes and suffixes
Year 3 introduction to suffix doubling rules for polysyllabic words is consolidated and applied more automatically in Year 4
Year 3 learning of homophones develops into Year 4 secure spelling of the full Years 3-4 homophones list
Year 3 introduction to etymological spelling patterns is consolidated and extended in Year 4, with pupils applying the full range of Years 3-4 patterns
Year 3 learning of the statutory word list continues in Year 4 until all words in the Years 3-4 list are securely known
Year 3 introduction to possessive apostrophe with plurals develops into Year 4 accurate placement across both regular and irregular plural nouns
Year 3 dictionary use for spelling develops into Year 4 more efficient dictionary use supported by growing spelling knowledge
Year 3 writing from dictation develops into Year 4 more demanding dictated sentences including all punctuation taught so far
Year 3 joining strokes in handwriting develops into Year 4 joined handwriting used throughout all independent writing as the norm
Year 3 handwriting quality and consistency develops into Year 4 increased fluency to keep pace with ideas, supporting composition and spelling
Year 3 planning from model texts develops into Year 4 more analytical study of model texts for structure, vocabulary and grammar to inform own writing
Year 3 generating and recording ideas develops into Year 4 more purposeful idea generation linked to audience, purpose and form
Year 3 oral rehearsal develops into Year 4 confident oral composition including dialogue, with growing understanding that writing differs from speech
Year 3 paragraphing as an organisational concept develops into Year 4 consistent and purposeful use of paragraphs to organise ideas around themes
Year 3 narrative elements develop into Year 4 more fully developed creation of setting, character and plot working together in coherent narratives
Year 3 organisational devices in non-narrative writing develops into Year 4 more confident and purposeful use of headings and sub-headings
Year 3 evaluating writing develops into Year 4 more independent and analytical assessment of effectiveness with specific suggestions for improvement
Year 3 editing for grammar and vocabulary develops into Year 4 more systematic proposed changes to improve consistency, including accurate pronoun use
Year 3 proof-reading develops into Year 4 more thorough and independent checking of all spelling and punctuation taught to date
Year 3 reading aloud own writing develops into Year 4 more polished oral presentation with controlled intonation, tone and volume
Year 3 multi-clause sentences with conjunctions develops into Year 4 extension with a wider range of conjunctions used more confidently and accurately
Year 3 introduction to present perfect tense develops into Year 4 secure understanding and accurate use in contrast to the simple past
Year 3 pronoun choice for cohesion develops into Year 4 consistent and accurate pronoun use within and across sentences to aid cohesion
Year 3 conjunctions, adverbs and prepositions for time and cause develops into Year 4 more confident and varied use across all three word classes
Year 3 introduction to fronted adverbials develops into Year 4 secure and accurate use including obligatory comma after fronted adverbials
Year 3 introduction to inverted commas for direct speech develops into Year 4 full direct speech punctuation including comma after reporting clause and end punctuation within inverted commas
Year 3 multi-clause sentence construction provides grammatical foundation for Year 4 expanded noun phrases which require understanding of noun phrase structure within sentences
Year 3 grammatical terminology including singular/plural provides foundation for Year 4 understanding the grammatical distinction between plural and possessive -s
Year 3 Standard English awareness develops into Year 4 accurate use of Standard English verb inflections instead of local spoken forms
Year 3 paragraphs to group related material develops into Year 4 purposeful use of paragraphs to organise ideas around a theme with cohesive pronoun/noun choice
Year 3 grammatical terminology provides the cumulative foundation for Year 4 new terms: determiner, pronoun, possessive pronoun, adverbial
Year 3 identification of effective language develops into Year 4 fuller understanding of figurative language, shades of meaning and academic vocabulary
Year 3 articulating and justifying opinions with support develops into Year 4 increasingly independent justification of views about texts, achieved fully by end of Year 4
Year 3 developing silent reading with understanding develops into Year 4 secure silent reading with good comprehension as the norm for independent reading
Year 3 word families knowledge supports Year 4 application of root word understanding to comprehend meaning of new vocabulary encountered in reading
Year 3 noun formation using prefixes supports Year 4 understanding of determiners and noun phrases as extended grammatical structures
Year 3 understanding of articles a/an (as determiners) provides foundation for Year 4 explicit learning of the term 'determiner'
